DICE Firmware Compiled on 8 Oct 2009
Main Page | Modules | Alphabetical List | Data Structures | Data Fields | Related Pages

Data Stream Parsing
[Programming Utilities]

Detailed Description

Utility functions for parsing tightly bit-packed packets, such as AV/C.

Given a chunk of memory this will allow the caller to parse a complex payload.

This module can be used from the command prompt by the cli_ds commands.

The "MODE" in which any stream operates, is entirely meant for the protection of data. Basically the idea is, that you don't want to be reading data which isn't valid, and you don't want to be writing over data which is already valid.

The DATASTREAM now uses the dsBuffer to read and write bytes in a QUADLET form. This means that in order for data to be written into the buffer, you must COMPLETE AN ENTIRE BYTE OF DATA. If you do not then the data is not written.


Data Structures

struct  DataStream

Function Documentation

HRESULT dsOpenStream (  pDataStream  pStream,
void *  data,
uint32  size,
uint32  mode
) 
 

This function takes a DataStream* in, and initializes it for use by dsWrite/Read functions.

Parameters:
pStream The new datastream
data This is the raw data which you intend to read as if it were a stream.
size This is the size in BYTES, of the data buffer.
mode Must be either dsMODE_READ or dsMODE_WRITE, depending upon the operations you wish to perform with this stream.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code.

HRESULT dsReOpenStream (  pDataStream  pStream,
uint32  mode
) 
 

Re-opens and re-initializes an already open datastream.

This function would typically be used to reuse a command packetBlock as the response packetBlock. This function also calls dsRESET so the stream will now be at the beginning.

Parameters:
pStream An existing datastream
mode Must be either dsMODE_READ or dsMODE_WRITE, depending upon the operations you wish to perform with this stream.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code.

HRESULT dsSwitchMode (  pDataStream  pStream,
uint32  mode
) 
 

This function switches the mode of a stream from Reading to Writing.

This is made to be an explicit change, so that you can't so easily go about mucking with valid values.

Parameters:
pStream An existing datastream
mode Must be either dsMODE_READ or dsMODE_WRITE, depending upon the operations you wish to perform with this stream.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code.

HRESULT dsCloseStream (  pDataStream  pStream  ) 
 

Closes a stream context.

Use this function when you are done with a stream and have no more use for it. This does not delete the data block passed into the dsOpenStream. Also it sets the stream context to invalid, so that any reads or writes using this stream context will cause an exception.

Parameters:
pStream An existing datastream to be closed.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code.

HRESULT dsReadBits (  pDataStream  pStream,
uint32  len,
uint32 *  data
) 
 

Read the specified number of bits from the data stream and adjust the position of the stream.

Parameters:
pStream An existing datastream to be used.
len The number of bits to read.
data The address to copy the read data into.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code.

NO_ERROR (0) or an error code.

HRESULT dsWriteBits (  pDataStream  pStream,
uint32  len,
uint32  data
) 
 

Write the specified number of bits to the data stream and adjust the position of the stream.

Note that an entire byte must be written before the data is actually written.

Parameters:
pStream An existing datastream to be used.
len The number of bits to write.
data The data to write to the stream.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code.

) 
 

Write 8 bits to the data stream and adjust the position of the stream.

data The data to write to the stream.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code.

HRESULT dsAddStream (  pDataStream  pDstStream,
pDataStream  pSrcStream
) 
 

This function is used for adding two streams together.

It may only be used on a whole byte boundary. Meaning neither stream can be anywhere except on a byte boundary. If the srcStream is too large to completely fit into the destination stream, you will receive an error, and the destination stream will not be affected.

Parameters:
pDstStream The destination stream to add on to.
pSrcStream The source stream to add.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code

HRESULT dsFastForward (  pDataStream  pStream,
uint32  count
) 
 

This function moves the current pointer ahead, 'count' bytes.

You will get an error if you run over the physical end of the data block passed into OpenStream.

This function requires that your current position is at the beginning of a complete byte. You may not be in the process of writing 2 bits, and then call this function. It will FAIL!

Parameters:
pStream The stream to advance.
count Number of BYTES to move forward.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code

HRESULT dsRewind (  pDataStream  pStream,
uint32  count
) 
 

This function moves the current pointer back, 'count' bytes.

You will get an error if you run over the physical start of the data block passed into OpenStream.

This function requires that your current position is at the beginning of a complete byte. You may not be in the process of writing 2 bits, and then call this function. It will FAIL!

Parameters:
pStream The stream to rewind.
count Number of BYTES to move back.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code

HRESULT dsReset (  pDataStream  pStream  ) 
 

This function resets the current position to the beginning of the data.

This works no matter which state the data stream is currently in. Unless of course the stream has been closed.

Parameters:
pStream The stream to reset
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code

uint32 dsGetPosition (  pDataStream  pStream  ) 
 

This function returns the current position pointer of the stream.

Parameters:
pStream The stream to use.
Returns:
The position in the stream.

void dsSetPosition (  pDataStream  pStream,
uint32  pos
) 
 

This sets the position to the indexed position specified.

This is indexed from the beginning of the data buffer.

Parameters:
pStream The stream to use.
pos The position to set.

void dsTrimSize (  pDataStream  pStream,
uint32  newsize
) 
 

This function changes the "SIZE" of the buffer, to the specified number.

WARNING : If you use this to GROW the buffer, make sure that the buffer you are using is big enough.

Parameters:
pStream The stream to trim.
newsize The new size for the data buffer.

HRESULT dsSetMarker (  pDataStream  pStream,
uint32  markerid
) 
 

Sets a marker in a data stream.

This allows for one function to pass a datastream to another function, and both functions would be able to know about the variable postion which marked the beginning of some position which would be well known.

Parameters:
pStream The stream to mark.
markerid The mark to set at the current position.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code

HRESULT dsKillMarker (  pDataStream  pStream,
uint32  markerid
) 
 

Remvoes a marker from a data stream.

Parameters:
pStream The stream to remove a marker from.
markerid The mark to remove.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code

HRESULT dsGotoMarker (  pDataStream  pStream,
uint32  markerid
) 
 

Set the position of a stream to an existing marker.

Parameters:
pStream The stream to use.
markerid The marker to locate to.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code

HRESULT dsReadChunk (  pDataStream  pStream,
uint32  size,
char *  buffer
) 
 

Read a chunk of data from the stream.

NOTICE: THE BUFFER SPECIFIED BY THE "buffer" PARAMETER, ** MUST ** START ON 4 BYTE BOUNDARY.

Parameters:
pStream The stream to use.
size The number of bytes to read.
buffer The buffer to place the read data into.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code

HRESULT dsWriteChunk (  pDataStream  pStream,
uint32  size,
char *  buffer
) 
 

Write a chunk of data into the stream.

NOTICE: THE BUFFER SPECIFIED BY THE "buffer" PARAMETER, ** MUST ** START ON 4 BYTE BOUNDARY.

Parameters:
pStream The stream to use.
size The number of bytes to write.
buffer The buffer to obtain data from.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code

HRESULT dsCopyStream (  pDataStream  destStream,
pDataStream  srcStream
) 
 

This function copy one stream's data to another stream, also copying the markers (which are in a valid range of the stream).

This does not cause an error if the sizes of the streams do not match. Instead the most data which can be copied, will be copied, and the extra data will be dropped silently.

Parameters:
destStream The destination data stream
srcStream The source data stream
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code

an ref ErrorCodes error code *HRESULT dsPadToEndOfQuadlet (  pDataStream  pStream,
BYTE  padbyte
) 
 

Pads the data stream to a quadlet boundary.

Parameters:
pStream The stream to pad.
padbyte The value to pad with.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code

HRESULT dsPadToEndOfBuffer (  pDataStream  pStream,
BYTE  padbyte
) 
 

Pads the data stream to the end of its buffer.

Parameters:
pStream The stream to pad.
padbyte The value to pad with.
Returns:
NO_ERROR (0) or an error code
